sponsoredBills: Proposal for a legislative amendment to the Constitution to provide resources for education and transportation through an additional tax on incomes in excess of one million dollars
Creates a 4% surtax on income above $1 million to fund education and transportation reinvestment.
Proposal for a legislative amendment to the Constitution to provide resources for education and transportation through an additional tax on incomes in excess of one million dollars
Creates a 4% surtax on income above $1 million to fund education and transportation reinvestment.
An Act providing rightful opportunities and meaningful investment for successful and equitable education
Fixes our outdated school funding formula to more accurately and equitably distribute resources – giving all schools the funding they need to deliver high-quality education.
An Act providing rightful opportunities and meaningful investment for successful and equitable education
Fixes our outdated school funding formula to more accurately and equitably distribute resources – giving all schools the funding they need to deliver high-quality education.
An Act to guarantee debt-free public higher education
Creates a higher education system where every Massachusetts resident has a right to attend any public college or university free of tuition and fees.
An Act to guarantee debt-free public higher education
Creates a higher education system where every Massachusetts resident has a right to attend any public college or university free of tuition and fees.
An Act relative to affordable and accessible high quality early education and care
Makes high-quality early education and child care affordable and accessible to all Massachusetts families.
An Act relative to affordable and accessible high quality early education and care
Makes high-quality early education and child care affordable and accessible to all Massachusetts families.
An Act establishing Medicare for All in Massachusetts
Establishes a single payer system, in which the state provides health care to all residents as a right.
An Act establishing Medicare for All in Massachusetts
Establishes a single payer system, in which the state provides health care to all residents as a right.
An Act supporting affordable housing with a local option for a fee to be applied to certain real estate transactions
Enables cities and towns to assess a fee of 0.5-2% on residential and commercial real estate transactions, with the funds allocated to affordable housing trust funds.
An Act supporting affordable housing with a local option for a fee to be applied to certain real estate transactions
Enables cities and towns to assess a fee of 0.5-2% on residential and commercial real estate transactions, with the funds allocated to affordable housing trust funds.
An Act to protect the civil rights and safety of all Massachusetts residents
Limits local and state police collaboration with federal immigration agents, bars law enforcement and court personnel from inquiring about immigration status, and ensures due process protections.
An Act to protect the civil rights and safety of all Massachusetts residents
Limits local and state police collaboration with federal immigration agents, bars law enforcement and court personnel from inquiring about immigration status, and ensures due process protections.
An Act to strengthen inmate visitation
Strengthens and secures the rights of prisoners to receive visits and maintain relationships with their friends and loved ones without unnecessary interference from the state.
An Act to strengthen inmate visitation
Strengthens and secures the rights of prisoners to receive visits and maintain relationships with their friends and loved ones without unnecessary interference from the state.
An Act promoting housing opportunity and mobility through eviction sealing
Requires the sealing of eviction records in order to combat housing discrimination.
An Act promoting housing opportunity and mobility through eviction sealing
Requires the sealing of eviction records in order to combat housing discrimination.
An Act removing obstacles and expanding access to women's reproductive health
Reforms our state’s abortion laws so that every person can control their own body, life, and future.
An Act to remove obstacles and expand abortion access
Reforms our state’s abortion laws so that every person can control their own body, life, and future.
An Act relative to election day registration

Eliminates the arbitrary and discriminatory 20-day registration cutoff and allows eligible residents to register or re-register--and vote--at the polls on Election Day and during the early voting period.
An Act relative to election day registration

Eliminates the arbitrary and discriminatory 20-day registration cutoff and allows eligible residents to register or re-register--and vote--at the polls on Election Day and during the early voting period.
An Act relative to ranked choice voting
Adopts ranked choice voting for relevant elections, enabling voters to rank candidate preferences and ensuring that the ultimate winner commands a majority of support.
An Act to use of ranked choice voting in elections
Adopts ranked choice voting for relevant elections, enabling voters to rank candidate preferences and ensuring that the ultimate winner commands a majority of support.
An Act promoting equality and respect in the legislature
Creates an independent commission to investigate and report on complaints of workplace and sexual harassment in the Massachusetts Legislature.
An Act promoting equality and respect in the legislature
Creates an independent commission to investigate and report on complaints of workplace and sexual harassment in the Massachusetts Legislature.
An Act relative to environmental justice and toxics reduction in the Commonwealth
Codifies environmental justice into law and secures strong enforcement of the state’s current EJ policy.
An Act relative to environmental justice and toxics reduction in the Commonwealth
Codifies environmental justice into law and secures strong enforcement of the state’s current EJ policy.
An Act re-powering Massachusetts with 100 percent renewable energy
Sets the goal of 100% renewable energy economy-wide by 2045 and 100% renewable electricity by 2035.
An Act transitioning Massachusetts to 100 percent renewable energy
Sets the goal of 100% renewable energy economy-wide by 2045 and 100% renewable electricity by 2035.
An Act to promote green infrastructure, reduce greenhouse gas emissions, and create jobs
Sets a price on carbon emissions to incentivize the transition to renewable energy, with parts of the resulting revenue allocated for sustainable infrastructure.
An Act to Promote Green Infrastructure and Reduce Carbon Emissions
Sets a price on carbon emissions to incentivize the transition to renewable energy, with parts of the resulting revenue allocated for sustainable infrastructure.
houseBills: Vote was to require copies of all bills to be made available to all members of the House and the public at least 72 hours before a vote.
Vote was to require at least 30 minutes for representatives to read an amendment before voting on it.
Vote was to make all submitted testimony and committee votes available to the public, as well as to provide representatives at least 24 hours to read a bill before voting on it in committee.

Vote was on prohibiting licensed mental health professionals from “practicing” on minors the damaging and homophobic/transphobic fraud of “conversion therapy,” which has the goal of “changing” a person’s sexual orientation or gender identity of a minor.

Vote was a conservative attempt to delay the elimination of a punitive welfare policy that denies benefits to children who were born while a family is receiving state assistance. MA is one of the only states to still do this.
Motion to recommit: An Act to raise the cap on kids

Vote was on making up to $8 million available for family planning clinics in Massachusetts at risk of losing federal funding under a new Trump administration rule that cuts support for providers that offer abortion services.

Vote was on overriding the Governor’s veto on a bill to eliminate a punitive welfare policy that denies benefits to children who were born while a family is receiving state assistance. MA is one of the only states to still do this.
Veto override: An Act to raise the cap on kids
Vote was on an amendment to make it more difficult for public sector workers to communicate while trying to form or operating a union.
Eliminating personal information and replacing with work contact only
Vote was on an amendment to make it more difficult for public sector unions to communicate with members about formal union buiness.
Eliminating union right to use public e-mail system
Vote was on allowing workers to film union organizing meetings without the consent of other workers.
Allow Employee recording of all meetings
Vote was on enabling bosses to threaten workers against joining a union.
Employer required to meet with employee and offer the employee the opportunity to opt out
Vote was on redundantly requiring the money from the Fair Share amendment to be spent on education and transportation, a conservative attempt to push anti-tax and anti-spending framing.
Ensuring that Funds Appropriated are in Addition to and Not In Lieu of Funds Already Appropriated for Such Purposes
Vote was on creating a corporate tax carveout in the Fair Share amendment.
Vote was on attempting to enable future Legislatures to set the surtax in the Fair Share amendment below 4% -- or even negate it entirely.
Vote was on attempting to enable future Legislatures to set the surtax in the Fair Share amendment below 4% -- or even negate it entirely.
Flexible Fair Share Amendment to allow future changes in rate without constitutional amendment
Vote was on lessening or negating the surtax—and requiring that every surtax on millionaires be matched with a tax cut.
Reducing the regressivity of the Fair Share Amendment by reducing rates of lower income taxpayers
Vote was on redundantly requiring the money from the Fair Share amendment to be spent on education and transportation, a conservative attempt to push anti-tax and anti-spending framing.
Vote was on advancing the Fair Share amendment, a 4% surtax on income above $1 million to fund education and transportation reinvestment, to the 2022 ballot.
Vote was on an amendment from Governor Charlie Baker to make it more difficult for public sector workers to organize a union.

Vote was on adding two commissioners to the body overseeing the director of the Office of Campaign and Political Finance to ensure that the commission does not consist solely of elected officials and that it contains people with independent legal, campaign, and elections experience.
Vote was on eliminating a $37 million tax cut specifically designed to help the wealthiest companies.
Removing tax cuts for large corporations
Vote was on increasing the spending on the drug war.
Vote was on creating new penalties for drug possession, doubling down on the failed drug war.
Vote was on updating the outdated education funding formula and investing $1.5 billion in additional money in our public schools, especially for the neediest students.

Legislator signed the "Voters Deserve to Know" transparency pledge committing to publish their committee votes online and to stand for recorded votes when their colleages request so for amendments or bills the legislator has co-sponsored.
senateBills: Vote was on increasing the notice for hearings from 48 hours to 72 hours and requiring the posting of recorded votes taken in committee online.
Vote was on providing representatives more notice when a Conference Committee produces a final bill for legislators to vote on (i.e., moving up the deadline from 8 pm to 5 pm the night before).

Vote was a conservative attempt to get the conversion therapy ban ruled unconstitutional. The ban, which passed, would prohibit licensed mental health professionals from “practicing” on minors the damaging and homophobic/transphobic fraud of “conversion therapy,” which has the goal of “changing” a person’s sexual orientation or gender identity of a minor.

Vote was on a proposal from Republican Governor Charlie Baker to make the adoption of a more stringent calculation of benefits (counting a parent's Supplemental Security Income in determining their children's eligibility for welfare benefits) a precondition of lifting the punitive "cap on kids."

Vote was on making up to $8 million available for family planning clinics in Massachusetts at risk of losing federal funding under a new Trump administration rule that cuts support for providers that offer abortion services.

Vote was on overriding the Governor’s veto on a bill to eliminate a punitive welfare policy that denies benefits to children who were born while a family is receiving state assistance. MA is one of the only states to still do this.
Vote was on establishing a gender-neutral identity option for Massachusetts licenses, a recognition that some individuals may not identify as either male or female.
An Act relative to gender identity on Massachusetts identification
Vote was on redundantly requiring the money from the Fair Share amendment to be spent on education and transportation, a conservative attempt to push anti-tax and anti-spending framing.
Ensuring that Funds Appropriated are in Addition to and Not In Lieu of Funds Already Appropriated for Such Purposes
Vote was on creating a corporate tax carveout in the Fair Share amendment.
Vote was on attempting to enable future Legislatures to set the surtax in the Fair Share amendment below 4% -- or even negate it entirely.
Vote was on attempting to enable future Legislatures to set the surtax in the Fair Share amendment below 4% -- or even negate it entirely.
Flexible Fair Share Amendment to allow future changes in rate without constitutional amendment
Vote was on lessening or negating the surtax—and requiring that every surtax on millionaires be matched with a tax cut.
Reducing the regressivity of the Fair Share Amendment by reducing rates of lower income taxpayers
Vote was on redundantly requiring the money from the Fair Share amendment to be spent on education and transportation, a conservative attempt to push anti-tax and anti-spending framing.
Vote was on advancing the Fair Share amendment, a 4% surtax on income above $1 million to fund education and transportation reinvestment, to the 2022 ballot.
Vote was on enabling bosses to prevent public sector workers from hosting union meetings at the office.
Prior Coordination for the Use of Government Facilities and Buildings
Vote was on an amendment to make it more difficult for public sector workers to communicate while trying to form or operating a union.
Vote was on an amendment from Governor Charlie Baker to the Janus bill to make it more difficult for public sector workers to organize a union.
Vote was on increasing the frequency of reviews of the education funding formula from every 10 years to every 5 years so that it never gets too out-of-date.
Vote was on increasing community and educator involvement in school districts' plans to reduce disparities -- and requires charter schools to create such plans as well.
Vote was on requiring a study of the impact on this regressive tax law on municipalities' ability to provide a high-quality education to all students.
Vote was on a regressive amendment to steer a greater percentage of total education spending toward more affluent districts.
Vote was on updating the outdated education funding formula and investing $1.5 billion in additional money in our public schools, especially for the neediest students.
Vote was on removing the ban on menthol cigarettes from the underlying bill.
Vote was on the House version of the plastic bag ban, which would have allowed retailers to use thicker single-use plastic bags and eliminated the fee for other single-use bags.
Vote was on nullifying the enforcement of the ban on single-use plastic bags and levying a small fee on other single-use bags.

Legislator signed the "Voters Deserve to Know" transparency pledge committing to publish their committee votes online and to stand for recorded votes when their colleages request so for amendments or bills the legislator has co-sponsored.
